results.content:
The course is very useful and informative and I learned a lot from it. I've been following Dennis Ivy since the starting of my career as django develepor. 

However, there are some points that are course specific but really important to mention.

1. Slugify the urls - While deploying the project in production level, it is important to slugify the urls as otherwise it would reveal the ids of the models used in django database. It is easier if working on django alone. However, I think its a tedious task when using react in the frontend and accessing the urls using api. 

2. Ecommerce websites are having a lot of functionalities and components in it. Clients might not be impressed by simple UI (as used in the course). It would be a better approach to use some bootstrap themes as UI and use their elements as react components. 

Thank you.
results.content_html:
The course is very useful and informative and I learned a lot from it. I've been following Dennis Ivy since the starting of my career as django develepor.

However, there are some points that are course specific but really important to mention.

1. Slugify the urls - While deploying the project in production level, it is important to slugify the urls as otherwise it would reveal the ids of the models used in django database. It is easier if working on django alone. However, I think its a tedious task when using react in the frontend and accessing the urls using api.

2. Ecommerce websites are having a lot of functionalities and components in it. Clients might not be impressed by simple UI (as used in the course). It would be a better approach to use some bootstrap themes as UI and use their elements as react components.

Thank you.

results.content:
This was a solid intro into used django as an api. It's pretty clear and bonus points for covering things like deployment and troubleshooting via heroku logs.

A few things to be aware of:

Redux is somewhat archaic. There's nothing wrong with it, infact it was one of the reasons I bought this course as I needed to learn it but it's not something you'd want to use for new builds unless you have specific circumstances. It's not bad, it's just a bit long winded.

Hosting/deployment - if you want decent speed these things will cost you. At mininum you'll  need to pay 7usd a month to get SSL on heroku.

Images - the use of images is basic, just a single image per product. You can develop this yourself of course.

SEO - the front end is built on react with hash router neither of which are SEO friendly. If you want product pages to be crawled by search engines...well this isn't for you tbh.

With all that said, this is a solid little course just don't expect to get an all singing, all dancing store made with bleeding edge tech. 

Finally, in defense of the lack of support in the QA - well most of these seem to be people wanting Dennis Ivy to debug their work - the main skill you need to develop as a dev. I've built it and it works as advertised.
results.content_html:
This was a solid intro into used django as an api. It's pretty clear and bonus points for covering things like deployment and troubleshooting via heroku logs.

A few things to be aware of:

Redux is somewhat archaic. There's nothing wrong with it, infact it was one of the reasons I bought this course as I needed to learn it but it's not something you'd want to use for new builds unless you have specific circumstances. It's not bad, it's just a bit long winded.

Hosting/deployment - if you want decent speed these things will cost you. At mininum you'll need to pay 7usd a month to get SSL on heroku.

Images - the use of images is basic, just a single image per product. You can develop this yourself of course.

SEO - the front end is built on react with hash router neither of which are SEO friendly. If you want product pages to be crawled by search engines...well this isn't for you tbh.

With all that said, this is a solid little course just don't expect to get an all singing, all dancing store made with bleeding edge tech.

Finally, in defense of the lack of support in the QA - well most of these seem to be people wanting Dennis Ivy to debug their work - the main skill you need to develop as a dev. I've built it and it works as advertised.

results.content: Too many typos, corrected too late. Some core concepts could have gotten an extra minute or two to explain. Lector doesn't seem to understand everything in detail, but rather taking it for granted (or as boilerplate, e.g. useState, useEffect). Still, it is great project and valuable content, which I'm sure comes with great effort.  This feedback is more for the lector to do better in future (or improve the course if possible), rather than something else. It's like putting 90% of the effort in it, and neglecting the remains, which for others as me might be critical. Thanks.
results.content_html: Too many typos, corrected too late. Some core concepts could have gotten an extra minute or two to explain. Lector doesn't seem to understand everything in detail, but rather taking it for granted (or as boilerplate, e.g. useState, useEffect). Still, it is great project and valuable content, which I'm sure comes with great effort. This feedback is more for the lector to do better in future (or improve the course if possible), rather than something else. It's like putting 90% of the effort in it, and neglecting the remains, which for others as me might be critical. Thanks.

results.content: It appears that Dennis is not comfortable with the material himself. He make very sloppy choices, the justification for some questionable design decisions is unconvincing, he made at least one big mistake which he overlooked and spoke over (and I'm not even at the half of the course). I'm experinced enough to be able to work around the faults and errors, and having a completed project he _can_ teach me what I need, and I _am_ learning new things - but it is not a good place to be for folks new to development and coding.
results.content_html: It appears that Dennis is not comfortable with the material himself. He make very sloppy choices, the justification for some questionable design decisions is unconvincing, he made at least one big mistake which he overlooked and spoke over (and I'm not even at the half of the course). I'm experinced enough to be able to work around the faults and errors, and having a completed project he _can_ teach me what I need, and I _am_ learning new things - but it is not a good place to be for folks new to development and coding.

results.content:
If you already know some Django and React, this is probably a 5 star course. If you dont know any Django or React, dont do this course if your objective is to learn how the technologies work. 

However, this course is aimed at developers who already have at least some exposure to the technologies used, and is more of a code-along for creating a functional e-commerce sites. Its a good course, but certain concepts could be explained more in depth, such as Redux
results.content_html:

Привет из Москвы ! 
It was great, sometimes i could not understand whats going on, why we are doing this and this, but not that, but later its understandable and make sense.

Anyway: Thank you so much, great course.

results.content:
I appreciate a lot Dennis' enthusiasm for this project. The project itself is quite nice, but I find it far from production standards. I would like to see a lot more defensive programming, having a lot more backend validation for forms and file types. I think it would also have been nice to get a bit more behind the scenes approach to how things work rather than so much code duplication and copy-pasting. 
Besides, I think deployment is far from ideal, and the way it's done makes it very cumbersome for automatic deployment on changes (or rather impossible). I would definitely have the build process done automatically, as well as the collection of static files.
I enjoyed the project but I believe it should be tweaked in order to be a realistic product a customer would pay for.
I still like a lot the idea of combining Django with React, and there are not many opportunities to see such a thing around, so I appreciate the opportunity.
Regrettably, the instructor is completely absent from the Q&A and despite the many bugs the app has and the many questions from students there are, he would never bother to take the time to reply and address his own mistakes.
results.content_html:
I appreciate a lot Dennis' enthusiasm for this project. The project itself is quite nice, but I find it far from production standards. I would like to see a lot more defensive programming, having a lot more backend validation for forms and file types. I think it would also have been nice to get a bit more behind the scenes approach to how things work rather than so much code duplication and copy-pasting.
Besides, I think deployment is far from ideal, and the way it's done makes it very cumbersome for automatic deployment on changes (or rather impossible). I would definitely have the build process done automatically, as well as the collection of static files.
I enjoyed the project but I believe it should be tweaked in order to be a realistic product a customer would pay for.
I still like a lot the idea of combining Django with React, and there are not many opportunities to see such a thing around, so I appreciate the opportunity.
Regrettably, the instructor is completely absent from the Q&A and despite the many bugs the app has and the many questions from students there are, he would never bother to take the time to reply and address his own mistakes.
